technical_concept: A Dockerfile is a text file with instructions to build a Docker image. Key instructions: FROM (base image to start from), RUN (execute commands during build), CMD (default command when container starts). Every Dockerfile must start with FROM. Real-world use: package your Java app so anyone can run it identically â€” no JDK installation needed on the target machine.

challenge.task: Write a Dockerfile that starts FROM eclipse-temurin:21, RUNs 'javac -version' to verify the compiler, and sets CMD to run 'java App'. Write each instruction on a new line.
challenge.hint: You need three lines: FROM, RUN, and CMD. The CMD should use exec form: CMD ["java", "App"]

dialogue.line: You've summoned creatures from existing blueprints. Now it's time to write your OWN spell scroll â€” a Dockerfile!
My own spell scroll! What goes into it?

Every scroll begins with FROM â€” the foundation spell. It declares which existing creature you're building upon. 'FROM eclipse-temurin:21' means 'start with a creature that already has Java 21 installed.'
So we stand on the shoulders of existing creatures?

Exactly! Then comes RUN â€” the transformation spell. 'RUN javac -version' verifies your creature's powers during creation. You can have many RUN spells â€” installing libraries, compiling code, anything!
And when the creature is summoned, what does it do?
That's CMD â€” the purpose spell. It tells the creature what to do when it awakens. 'CMD ["java", "App"]' means 'when summoned, run the Java application.' Every creature needs a purpose!
FROM for foundation, RUN for teaching, CMD for purpose. Let me try!
Write your scroll in the console below. Three lines: the foundation, the teaching, and the purpose.
Okay, things are getting serious. It's time to create your first Dockerfile. Think of it as... writing your dating profile.
First line: FROM. That's your background. 'FROM eclipse-temurin:21' â€” it says where you come from, what you're built on. In this case: Java 21. Everyone starts somewhere.
Okay, so FROM is like 'Originally from...' on a profile.
Exactly. Then RUN â€” that's your skills and experience. 'RUN javac -version' means 'let me show you what I can do.' You can list as many skills as you want.
CMD is what you're looking for. Your purpose. 'CMD ["java", "App"]' â€” 'I'm here to run this application.' It's the 'what I bring to the relationship' part. Every good profile needs one.
FROM, RUN, CMD. Background, skills, purpose. This is actually making sense.
